contentrichtext.text: {{redirect|Yarraman|the railway station of the same name in Melbourne|Yarraman railway station}} {{Infobox Australian place | type = town | name = Yarraman | state = qld | image = Yarraman-Catholic.JPG | caption = Our Lady of Dolours Roman Catholic church in Yarraman | lga = [[Toowoomba Region]] | postcode = 4614 | est = | latd = 26 | latm = 50 | lats = 21 | longd = 151 | longm = 58 | longs = 39 | pushpin_label_position = left | pop = 945 | pop_footnotes=<ref name="ABS 2006"/> | elevation= 407 | elevation_footnotes= | maxtemp = | mintemp = | rainfall = | stategov = [[Electoral district of Nanango|Nanango]] | fedgov = [[Division of Maranoa|Maranoa]] | county = [[County of Cavendish, Queensland|Cavendish]] | parish = Cooyar | dist1 = 181 | dir1 = NW | location1= [[Brisbane]] | dist2 = 118 | dir2 = N | location2= [[Toowoomba, Queensland|Toowoomba]] | dist3 = 44 | dir3 = S | location3= [[Kingaroy, Queensland|Kingaroy]] }} '''Yarraman''' is a town in [[Queensland]], [[Australia]]. The town is located {{convert|181|km|mi|0}} northwest of the state capital, [[Brisbane]] on the junction of the [[New England Highway|New England]] and [[D'Aguilar Highway|D'Aguilar]] highways. ==History== The creek at Yarraman was used in the 1870s as a place for local [[graziers]] and [[Stockman (Australia)|stockmen]] to meet and trade [[cattle]]. The township was established in the late 1870s.<ref name="South Burnett Net: Yarraman">[http://www.thecomputertechnicalcentre.com/Southburnett/yarraman.htm South Burnett Net: Yarraman], accessed 17 Jan 2010</ref> A [[school]] was opened in 1910.<ref name="South Burnett Net: Yarraman"/> As there were many large [[Hoop Pine]] forests in the area, a [[timber mill]] was established in 1910.<ref name="South Burnett Net: Yarraman"/> The town was connected to [[Brisbane]] and [[Ipswich, Queensland|Ipswich]] by [[railway]] in 1913.<ref name="South Burnett Net: Yarraman"/> The railway line was closed in 1988.<ref name="qp">[http://queenslandplaces.com.au/yarraman Queensland Places: Yarraman], accessed 17 Jan 2010</ref> === Census data === Based on data gathered through the [[Census in Australia|census]], Yarraman's population has grown as shown below. {| class="wikitable" border="1" |- ! Year ! Number of people ! Census data link |- | 2001 | 897 |<ref name="ABS 2001">{{Census 2001 AUS |id=UCL362600 |name=Yarraman (L) (Urban Centre/Locality) |accessdate=2010-01-17 |quick=on}}</ref> |- | 2006 | 945 |<ref name="ABS 2006">{{Census 2006 AUS |id=UCL362600 |name=Yarraman (L) (Urban Centre/Locality) |accessdate=2007-12-30 |quick=on}}</ref> |} ==Today== Yarraman is set in a fertile valley and produces [[timber]], [[cereal|grain]] and [[beef]] and [[dairy]] goods, which it exports to larger cities.{{Citation needed|date=December 2007}} It has a community radio station [http://4who.org.au Wild Horse FM 99.7]. It is served by three churches: St Philip's Anglican Church, Our Lady of Dolours Catholic Church, and Calvary Lutheran church. Yarraman is surrounded by the various components of the fragmentary Bunya Mountains and Yarraman [[Important Bird Area]] which contains the largest remaining population of the [[Vulnerable species|vulnerable]] [[Black-breasted Button-quail]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.birdata.com.au/iba.vm |title=IBA: Bunya Mountains & Yarraman|accessdate=2011-06-08 |work= Birdata |first= |last= |publisher=Birds Australia |date= }}</ref> ==References== {{reflist}} == External links == {{Commons category}} * [http://www.yarraman.net Community website] * [http://queenslandplaces.com.au/yarraman Queensland Places: Yarraman] * [http://www.thecomputertechnicalcentre.com/Southburnett/yarraman.htm South Burnett Net: Yarraman] * [http://www.chapelhill.homeip.net/FamilyHistory/Photos/Yarraman-Rosalie/ Yarraman cemetery headstone photos] {{Darling Downs}} [[Category:Towns in Queensland]] [[Category:Towns in the Darling Downs]]
